This is an interesting question because it sheds light on how science is done. Debate isn’t as big a part of scientific discovery as the average person might think. That’s not to say there have never been debates in science. Debates were bigger in the early 20th century. Einstein used to debate quantum physics with Neils Bohr. (Final score, Bohr 14, Einstein 0). Bohr–Einstein debates - Wikipedia There was a rather famous event that was actually called “The Great Debate”, held in 1920, on whether there were other galaxies. At the time, telescopes weren’t good enough to see other galaxies. The Andromeda Galaxy has been observed, but it was impossible to see how far away it was, or to identify individual stars, so they called it the Andromeda Nebula. Two scientists debated whether the Milky Way was the Universe, or if there were other galaxies. Great Debate (astronomy) - Wikipedia Here’s the point. Debates are fun. Debates can be entertaining and can fill an auditorium, but the “Great Debate” didn’t answer the question. What did answer the question was a better telescope 3 years later, when Edwin Hubble provided the first solid evidence that there was a star outside the Milky Way. Other galaxies exist The 100 inch Hooker telescope was completed in 1917, but it wasn’t until 6 years later that the more distant stars were observed and confirmed by Mr. Hubble. (or is that Dr. Hubble). Mount Wilson Observatory - Wikipedia I always thought we should make a joke about that, like, Edwin Hubble used Hookers, but . . . it’s probably not very funny. Here’s the point. The debate solved nothing. The telescope and Edwin Hubble solved everything. Science doesn’t use debate to move forward, it requires evidence, and people smart enough to understand the evidence. Getting back to Einstein vs. Bohr (not to bore anyone . . . he he, see what I did there), and this will come back to global warming, I promise. A physicist named John Stewart Bell didn’t like the general acceptance that Bohr was right. Bohr’s definition of how quantum physics worked bothered him, and he wrote a paper about it in 1964, which wasn’t published until 1966, and raised some debate (there’s that word again), on the Einstein vs. Bohr disagreement on how quantum physics worked. But, that’s an oversimplification. John von Newman wrote an argument that some people said “proved” Bohr was right and Einstein wrong. Don’t get me started on the use of the word “proof”, which is often used out of convenience, but never truly accurate in science. Proof is a mathematical word, but out of convenience, we use the word incorrectly, fairly often, in science. It was common among professors, at the time, to say that von Newmann’s argument proved Bohr correct. John Stewart Bell - Wikipedia The problem. There was a flaw in von Newmann’s proof, and let me just point out, John von Newmann was brilliant. He was a mathematician, a physicist and one of the key designers of modern computers, so, he deserves mad respect. A flaw in his “proof” doesn’t take away the brilliant contributions he made to science, just as Einstein being wrong about quantum physics doesn’t undo his brilliance. Nobody is going to be right about cutting edge physics every time, in fact, just being smart enough to make a wrong argument speaks well of a scientist’s abilities. First you have to understand it, then you can make an argument that may turn out to be right or may turn out to be wrong / both are valid for publishing if the science is sound. https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/wronger-than-wrong/ Not even wrong - Wikipedia So, von Newmann’s intelligent argument had a flaw, that was identified in 1935, by Grete Hermann, but her correction went unnoticed, perhaps because (and I’m tempted to say, probably because) she was a woman, and as a result, von Newmann’s argument was taught in universities as a “proof” of Neils Bohr’s no hidden-variable theorem for about 30 years. Imagine that. For 30 years, a correction went unnoticed. I can’t emphasize that enough, at least, until John Bell, who made the same observation as Grete Hermann (and Bell is an everyday name in physics, Hermann is not - there is no fairness in this world sometimes) Grete Hermann - Wikipedia But, Bell, like Hermann, found the flaw in von Newmann’s argument. Bell identified this in 1964 but had some details to work out and some delays and wasn’t published until 1966, and a few years later, in 1972 the first Bell’s test as done and it came down on the side of Bohr. Interestingly, Bell thought Einstein was right, and Bohr was wrong. His test, came down on the side of Bohr. So, I’m going to have some fun with words. Einstein’s argument was logical, reasonable, and wrong. Bohr’s argument was counter-intuitive, and right von Newman’s argument, ended up being technically right, on the no hidden-variable argument, but had an error. It wasn’t a sound argument. It didn’t demonstrate what von Newmann clalimed. Bell’s belief was wrong, but his test was sound and wound up demonstrating that Bohr was right. Got all that? You have to be smart and understand something, and you have to understand something before you can be wrong and being wrong, frankly, it’s OK, because right or wrong isn’t the issue, what counts is what can be shown, or word I don’t like “proved”. Like Tom Cruise said in that movie. “It doesn't matter what I believe. It only matters what I can prove. So don't tell me . . . “ Kaffee: I know the LAW quote Debate doesn’t answer questions, it raises them . . . which is OK, but it’s not an answer. Evidence answers questions. “Was there ever a debate” isn’t the right question, the question you should be asking is “is there evidence” and the answer to that question is yes. Mountains of evidence. That’s why the vast majority of scientists understand and agree with the man made climate change argument - because it’s sound, and it passed many tests, and every year the evidence gets stronger. People often say 97% of scientists agree with man made climate change, well, frankly, those who understand it, it’s more like 99.8% and the 0.2% who don’t, most of them don’t agree in exchange for a paycheck, or for some philosophical “lets keep an open mind reason because, I also want to keep an open mind on vaccines causing cancer and tin foil hats blocking telepathy. We don’t need a debate, we need people who don’t agree to put their time and effort into reviewing the evidence, and if they can find flaw - not jibberish, but actual flaw, then scientists will listen. And, yes, once in a while, the scientific community will miss a correction, or not understand a new discovery. Einstein’s 1905 publications were met with silence for 6 months, until Max Planck sent a messenger to in, inviting him to his institute, which, if you think about it, is really quite something, for a couple of reasons. New ideas often take time to digest, though at the time, it bothered Einstein, and lead him to doubt his own work for a while, but what’s cool, is that Max Planck was the premier physicist in the world at the time, and Planck had taken an interest in Einstein’s work. To put that in modern terms, it’s like submitting an script to a movie studio, not hearing a peep for 6 months, then one day, Francis Ford Coppola knocks on your door and tells you that he’s going to make your movie. Einstein’s ideas were very different and it took time for the scientific community to accept them, and if not for Max Planck, it might have been quite a bit longer before Einstein’s ideas went mainstream. But, I digress. I just like that story that Einstein went from 6 months of silence to an invitation from the top physicist in the world, one day, and he went from the patent office, to fame, almost overnight, because Max Planck recognized his brilliance. It’s a bit like the Ramanujan story about the genius discovered, as story which has had a movie made of it, and many people know. Einstein’s 6 months of waiting is rarely mentioned, but it must have been a very trying time for him. I’ve heard climate skeptics compare themselves to Galileo, which could not be more wrong. Galileo wasn’t tried for his science. He was tried for disagreeing with scripture. Galileo brought his evidence to court. He was prepared to argue his reasons for how he know Venus orbited the sun, or why tides followed the Sun and Moon, but his science was never questioned, only that scripture said this and Galileo said that - and based on scripture and scripture along, Galileo was found guilty. If he’d lived in a nation where the church wasn’t so powerful, Galileo’s ideas would probably not have lead to a lifetime house arrest and nearly his death. Galileo also was very good at making enemies. He called fellow professors and high ranking church officials “morons” regularly, so, his tongue as as much to blame for his trial as his science. Galileo is a terrible example of science misunderstood, because pretty much every scientist with any skill at all, in his day who looked at Galileo’s work, found his arguments compelling, believable and verifiable. Anyone could look through his telescopes and see that Jupiter’s moons orbited Jupiter, not Earth. Grete Hermann is a good example of when good science goes missed or ignored. Galileo really isn’t an example of that. Galileo’s science moved through the scientific community almost like a brush-fire, with rapid (for the time) acceptance and agreement, the only difference being, the scientific community was less comfortable publishing things that disagreed with scripture in those days. So . . . long and story filled answer is done. This is what matters. Debate isn’t required. Only evidence. Understanding the evidence is required. Almost to a man, people who don’t accept man made climate change don’t understand how strong the evidence is. If you want to disprove an argument in science, and convince scientists - make a logically consistent argument or find the errors in the accepted argument. So called climate “skeptics” don’t do that. They’re not even trying to do science, they just do propaganda. Propaganda isn’t evidence, even if sells to a large number of people. If any climate skeptic thinks they have a real argument, I invite them to share it, because they’ve never presented a sound argument. Everything they claim can be debunked. Man made climate change can’t be debunked, because it’s backed by evidence. The last time team “skeptic” did any real science, the science agreed with man made global warming. Their study showed even more man made warming than NASA, NOAA or HadCRU. After that, team “skeptic” has switched gears to nothing but propaganda. Converted Contrarian Argues Humans "Almost Entirely" to Blame for Climate Change There’s a guy on Quora who makes the claim that man made climate change is un-falsifiable. That’s a bogus claim. The studies on man made climate change could have gone either way. Just because something hasn’t been falsified, doesn’t mean it wasn’t un-falsifiable. That’s not splitting hairs. That’s fundamental. So, until climate “skeptics” start understanding science, this is my answer to every climate change skeptic out there. “You’re no Grete Hermann, and you don’t even know enough to be wrong.” I’d respect them, if they’d reach the level of actually being wrong. They’re below that. So, please, get an education and stop “debating” until you understand the evidence that’s already out there.

Has there actually been a scientific debate over global warming? There has been plenty of debates over global warming from the 70s onwards, but lately the only debate concerns the speed of warming and what will be effective against it. There have been counter arguments made against anthropogenic global warming (AGW) such as the article titled "500 Scientists Whose Research Contradicts Man-Made Global Warming Scares", written by a food policy analyst Dennis T Avery of the Hudson Institute and was published by The Heartland Institute in 2007. The list was immediately called out for citing discredited work, misunderstanding the findings and generally seeking to distort the truth. Many of the scientists that were mentioned tried to get their names removed because of the misrepresentation of their work, but the Heartland Institute refused to comply. At present the more qualified the researcher, the higher the consensus is concerning the reality of AGW, although there is plenty of room for argument concerning the accuracy of models and the strategies that can be employed.  According to the United States National Research Council, [T]here is a strong, credible body of evidence, based on multiple lines of research, documenting that climate is changing and that these changes are in large part caused by human activities. While much remains to be learned, the core phenomenon, scientific questions, and hypotheses have been examined thoroughly and have stood firm in the face of serious scientific debate and careful evaluation of alternative explanations. * * * Some scientific conclusions or theories have been so thoroughly examined and tested, and supported by so many independent observations and results, that their likelihood of subsequently being found to be wrong is vanishingly small. Such conclusions and theories are then regarded as settled facts. This is the case for the conclusions that the Earth system is warming and that much of this warming is very likely due to human activities. Science is a continual debate based on research, published papers, peer review, and specialist conferences. This process never ends and is never totally “settled”, since there is always new information and discoveries to bring to the table. This is why the term “law of science” has fallen by the wayside except as a mark of respect for the greats like Newton, now preferring the term theory, since it implies that there is still room for improvement.

Let’s define a couple of the other types of debate we are exposed to. Formal debate - This is typically done in clubs in context of academic settings. Individuals take positions on a single issue, whether they believe them or not, and argue with another individual, typically in a moderated setting and under specific rules of order that keep the debate on track. The vast majority of people never witness a formal debate. It’s a scored game of rhetoric, not a meaningful intellectual exercise most of the time. Political debate - During campaigns, politicians end up on stage together and some moderator asks a series of questions of each of the politicians. Often this results in canned platform responses and politicians staying on message rather than responding, but it does lead to emotional theater which sways some people. It’s not typically meaningful in terms of semantic comment, and once again is more an opportunity for jostling for position of a certain type. The smaller the number of politicians on stage and the better the moderators, the more it becomes meaningful. But it’s still an exercise in messaging not in intellectual discovery or logical step-by-step refinement of an argument. Lots of people end up watching them in much the same way that they watch horse races and football. They cheer their team, boo the other team and go home thinking something happened when nothing really did. Some number of people get together and argue vague positions badly, often while acting under the influence of undergraduate education or social media. Almost everyone has witnessed or participated in this, including yours truly. These forms of debate are notable for their unity of location, members and time. They occur, then it’s like the discussion never happened.  Then there’s scientific debate. It’s very, very different than the others above. First off, it takes a long time, sometimes decades. Secondly, it takes place in two forums, peer-reviewed scientific journals and to a lesser extent conferences and classrooms. Thirdly, it takes place among a lot more people. Finally, it isn’t human beings talking at and over one another, it’s written and documented. Scientific papers have up to a dozen authors, after a team has moved through an experiment to publication. Peer-reviewers moderate what content gets into journals. Completely unrelated groups in the same field critique the published paper in the form of formal letters to the editor pointing out challenges, or in the form of additional peer-reviewed papers contradicting, supporting or refining the results. Typically different data sets and methodologies are used to assess consilience. Unlike the debates above, it’s not 2–10 people on a stage for a couple of hours, it’s an ongoing set of theories, hypotheses, experiments and publication that sometimes takes years or decades to finally establish results that are generally agreed upon. Scientific paradigms do not arise overnight. What scientific debate doesn’t have is one person taking a position against the evidence, and one person taking a position for the evidence talking in a formal or semi-formal setting and reality being decided by who is the better speaker. That’s another thing that occurs with scientific debate that rarely occurs with other things that are called debate. The opinions of the people engaged in scientific debate often changes. The evidence convinces them. Scientific debate that is occurring around global warming right now is around edge conditions, model refinement and about data set / methodology pairs which disagree and why.
